facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 123 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 123 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 28, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in A.I.T. Reference No. 16 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated November 28, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in A.I.T. Reference No. 16 of 1960. T. Desai and O. P. Rana, for the appellant.

facts.text: On May 14, 1949, the Sub-Divisional Officer, Jaunpur, assessed the respondent under S. 16(3) of the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 for the account period 1355 Fasli (July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948) on a net income of Rs. 72,769/15/2.

anchor.surface_text: By order, dated May 14, 1949 the Sub-Divisional Officer, Jaunpur, assessed Raja Yadvendra Dutt Dube hereinafter called the respondent-under S. 16 3  of the U. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 to pay agricultural income-tax for the account period 1355 Fasli  July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948  on a net income of Rs. 72,769/15/2.

facts.text: On June 9, 1950, the Collector of Jaunpur recomputed tax under S. 25 read with s. 16(4) of the Act for the said account period on a total net income of Rs. 80,859/13/6.

anchor.surface_text: Being of the view that a part of the income of the respondent had escaped assessment, the Collector of Jaunpur by order, dated June 9, 1950, recomputed tax under S. 25 read with s. 16 4  of the Act for the said account period on a total net income of Rs. 80,859/13/6.

facts.text: On March 5, 1952, the Agricultural Income-tax Commissioner set aside the orders of the Collector and the Sub-Divisional Officer and directed fresh assessment by the Collector after notice to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the respondent the Agricultural Income-tax Commissioner by order dated March 5, 1952, set aside the orders of the Collector and also of the Sub- Divisional Officer and directed that the assessment be reopened by the Collector and fresh assessment of the income for 1355 Fasli be made after giving numberice to the respondent.

facts.text: The Commissioner held that the assessment by the Sub-Divisional Officer was without jurisdiction and the Collector's reassessment order also lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Commissioner, assessment made by the Sub-Divisional Officer was without jurisdiction, and the order of reassessment by the Collector being in review and substitution of the order of assessment, want of jurisdiction in the order of assessment attached to the order of reassessment as well.

facts.text: The respondent moved the Board of Revision against the Commissioner's order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Board of Revision against the order of the Commissioner.

facts.text: On October 15, 1952, the Board of Revision declared the Sub-Divisional Officer's assessment order illegal, set it aside suo motu, set aside the Commissioner's order, and directed fresh assessment according to law.

anchor.surface_text: However, the Board observed, the illegality and invalidity of the order of assessment having companye to their numberice, they would take up the matter suo motu in exercise of their revisional jurisdiction and declare the order passed by the Sub-Divisional Officer as illegal and set it aside.

facts.text: The Board referred under s. 24(4) of the Act the question: Whether on the facts and having regard to s.25, the Board could on 15th October 1952 direct fresh assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in setting aside the order of the Commissioner, they also set aside the order of assessment made by the Sub-Divisional Officer, and directed that Fresh assessment will be made according to law. The Board then referred under s. 24 4  of the Act the following question of law to the High Court of Allahabad for opinion

facts.text: Allahabad High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and having regard to the provisions of section 25 of the Act, the Board companyld on the 15th October, 1952, direct a fresh assessment to be made ? The High Court, recorded an answer in the negative.

facts.text: The State of Uttar Pradesh appealed to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, recorded an answer in the negative. The State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Assessing authority under the Act is a person authorised by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Act are briefly these Assessing authority under the Act means a person authorised by the State Government to assess agricultural income-tax s. 2 6 .

facts.text: Every Collector and Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division is assessing authority; Assistant Collector for gross agricultural income not exceeding Rs. 1 lakh; Collector for all cases.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this Act, every Collector, and Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division shall be assessing authority and shall exercise and perform within his revenue jurisdiction such powers and duties as may be prescribed, provided that the State Government may appoint any officer as an assessing authority for such area as may be prescribed. In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub- section  1 , the following authorities shall be the assessing authorities in the cases mentioned against each namely Assistant Collector Incharge of sub- division.

facts.text: The respondent filed return in pursuance of a notice under s.15(3).

It is companymon ground however that the respondent filed the return in pursuance of a numberice under s. 15 3 ,

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer found that gross agricultural income of respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer lacked jurisdiction because gross income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The order of assessment passed by the Sub-Divisional Officer was set aside by the Board because the Sub-Divisional Officer had numberjurisdiction to assess to tax income of a person whose gross agricultural income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh,

facts.text: Notice under s.15(3) was issued by Sub-Divisional Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice under S. 15 3  was issued to the respondent by the Sub-Divisional Officer, presumably on the assumption that the gross agricultural income of the respondent did number exceed Rs. 1 lakh

facts.text: Board did not expressly set aside the notice under s.15(3) but effectively quashed it by directing fresh assessment after notice.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Board of Revision did number expressly Set aside the numberice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer under S. 15  3 , but the Board agreed with the Commissioner that the original order of assessment passed by the Sub- Divisional Officer was absolutely without jurisdiction,

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's negative answer.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in the answer which it recorded.

facts.text: Collector issued notice under s.25 within time, but it was set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector issued a numberice under s. 25 for reassessing income which had escaped assessment and assessed the income of the respondent, but the proceeding of the Collector was set aside as unauthorised,

facts.text: Fresh assessment requires new notice under s.15(3) or s.25, which is time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: and the Collector was directed to start a fresh proceeding for assessment. The numberice issued by the Collector must also be deemed to be quashed. The Collector has, therefore, under the direction given by the Board, to issue a fresh numberice before a proceeding for assessment may be started,

issues.text: Whether on the facts and having regard to the provisions of section 25 of the Act, the Board could on the 15th October, 1952, direct a fresh assessment to be made?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and having regard to the provisions of section 25 of the Act, the Board companyld on the 15th October, 1952, direct a fresh assessment to be made ?

issues.text: whether the Board had authority on the view expressed by it to make the order directing re-assessment, and that question must be decided in the light of the provisions of s. 15 3 and S. 25 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are only companycerned to deal with the limited question whether the Board had authority on the view expressed by it to make the order directing re- assessment, and that question must be decided in the light of the provisions of s. 15 3  and S. 25 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether, since the notice under S. 15(3) issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer was not set aside, the Collector in making the order of assessment pursuant to the order of the Board will not be transgressing any statutory restrictions imposed by s. 15(3) or S. 25 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State raised three companytentions in support of the plea that the Board had power to direct the Collector to make a fresh assessment The Sub-Divisional Officer was invested with authority to issue a numberice under S. 15 3  calling for a return, and since this numberice was number set aside by the Commissioner or by the Board of Revision,

issues.text: Whether without a fresh notice under s. 15(3), the Collector has the power, by virtue of the notice under s. 15(1), to assess the income of the respondent on the return made pursuant to the notice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer

anchor.surface_text: Without a fresh numberice under s. 15 3 , the Collector has the power, by virtue of the numberice under s. 15 1 , to assess the income of the respondent on the return made pursuant to the numberice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer.

issues.text: Whether since notice under s. 25 of the Act for reassessment of the escaped income was issued within the period prescribed by s. 25(3), and the notice was otherwise valid, assessment proceedings directed by the Board may be founded by the Collector on that notice

anchor.surface_text: Since numberice under s. 25 of the Act for reassessment of the escaped income was issued within the period prescribed by s. 25 3 , and the numberice was otherwise valid, assessment proceedings directed by the Board may be founded by the Collector on that numberice.

issues.text: Whether by the expression 'without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section (1)' in sub-s. (2) of s. 14 power is intended to be conferred upon the Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division to assess income of an assessee whose gross agricultural income exceeds Rs. 1 lakh

anchor.surface_text: The companytention raised by companynsel for the State that by the expression without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section  1  in sub-s.  2  of s. 14 power is intended to be companyferred upon the Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division to assess income of an assessee whose gross agricultural income exceeds Rs. 1 lakh cannot be accepted.

issues.text: The question whether the order passed by the Board setting aside the orders of assessment of the Sub-Divisional Officer and of the Collector and even of the Commissioner is justifiable in law

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the order passed by the Board setting aside the orders of a assessment of the Sub-Divisional Officer and of the Collector and even of the Commissioner is justifiable in law is number referred to us.

arguments.claim: The Sub-Divisional Officer was invested with authority to issue a notice under S. 15(3) calling for a return, and since this notice was not set aside by the Commissioner or the Board of Revision, the Collector will not be transgressing any statutory restrictions imposed by s. 15(3) or S. 25 in making the order of assessment pursuant to the order of the Board.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State raised three contentions in support of the plea that the Board had power to direct the Collector to make a fresh assessment The Sub-Divisional Officer was invested with authority to issue a notice under S. 15 3 calling for a return, and since this notice was not set aside by the Commissioner or by the Board of Revision,

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice issued by Sub-Divisional Officer was unauthorised as he lacked jurisdiction once gross income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh; Board effectively quashed it by setting aside assessment order.

arguments.claim: Without a fresh notice under s. 15(3), the Collector has the power, by virtue of the notice under s. 15(1), to assess the income of the respondent on the return made pursuant to the notice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer.
arguments.court_reasoning: Proceedings based on invalid special notice cannot rely on general notice years later; fresh s.15(3) notice required but time-barred.

arguments.claim: Since notice under s. 25 of the Act for reassessment of the escaped income was issued within the period prescribed by s. 25(3), and the notice was otherwise valid, assessment proceedings directed by the Board may be founded by the Collector on that notice.
arguments.court_reasoning: Collector's s.25 notice and proceedings set aside as unauthorised; fresh notice required under Board's direction, but now time-barred.

arguments.claim: By the expression 'without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section (1)' in sub-s. (2) of s. 14, power is intended to be conferred upon the Assistant Collector (Sub-Divisional Officer) to assess income of an assessee whose gross agricultural income exceeds Rs. 1 lakh.
arguments.court_reasoning: Sub-ss. 1 and 2 read together limit SDO to cases under Rs. 1 lakh; Collector has unlimited jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Assessment by Sub-Divisional Officer was without jurisdiction because gross income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh; Collector's reassessment invalid as substitution/review of invalid order.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Commissioner, assessment made by the Sub-Divisional Officer was without jurisdiction, and the order of reassessment by the Collector being in review and substitution of the order of assessment, want of jurisdiction in the order of assessment attached to the order of reassessment as well.

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity of setting aside not referred; direction for fresh assessment rejected as requiring time-barred notice.

arguments.claim: Under s.14, Collector has unlimited jurisdiction; Assistant Collector (SDO) only where gross agricultural income does not exceed Rs. 1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this Act, every Collector, and Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division shall be assessing authority... Assistant Collector Incharge of sub- division. Where the gross agricultural income does not exceed Rs. 1 lakh. Collector In all cases.

arguments.claim: Taxing authority has power to decide preliminary jurisdictional facts (gross income) subject to superior court rectification.

anchor.surface_text: as in other taxing statutes where the taxing authority is constituted a tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction the authority has the power, subject to rectification by a superior Court, to decide facts on the proof of which his jurisdiction depends.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.15(3) issued by SDO unauthorised once gross income found to exceed Rs. 1 lakh; entire proceedings invalid unless conclusion set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The notice under S. 15 3  was issued to the respondent by the Sub-Divisional Officer... When he arrived at the conclusion that the gross income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, the proceeding initiated by the Sub-Divisional Officer including the issue of notice must... be held unauthorised.

arguments.claim: Board effectively quashed the s.15(3) notice by declaring assessment without jurisdiction and directing fresh assessment after notice.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Board of Revision did not expressly Set aside the notice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer under S. 15  3 , but the Board agreed with the Commissioner that the original order of assessment passed by the Sub- Divisional Officer was absolutely without jurisdiction,

arguments.claim: Fresh assessment requires new notice under s.15(3) or s.25, both now time-barred after end of assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: and the Collector was directed to start a fresh proceeding for assessment. The notice issued by the Collector must also be deemed to be quashed. The Collector has, therefore, under the direction given by the Board, to issue a fresh notice before a proceeding for assessment may be started,

arguments.claim: High Court right in answering negatively that Board could not direct fresh assessment on Oct 15, 1952 under s.25.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in the answer which it recorded.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the Board could not on 15th October 1952 direct a fresh assessment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board's direction requires fresh notice under s.15(3) or s.25; prior notices unauthorised and quashed; both time-barred by 1952.

holdings.text: Sub-Divisional Officer had no jurisdiction to assess income where gross agricultural income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The order of assessment passed by the Sub-Divisional Officer was set aside by the Board because the Sub-Divisional Officer had no jurisdiction to assess to tax income of a person whose gross agricultural income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, and the Board agreed with the Commissioner that the order of the Collector being in review or substitution of the order of the Sub-Divisional Officer was also liable to be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14(2) limits Assistant Collector to cases <= Rs.1 lakh gross income; Collector has unlimited jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Under s.14(1) and (2), Collector has unlimited jurisdiction; Assistant Collector (Sub-Divisional Officer) only where gross agricultural income does not exceed Rs. 1 lakh.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of sub-ss.(1),(2); rejects 'without prejudice' expanding SDO power.

holdings.text: Taxing authority constituted as tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction has power to decide preliminary jurisdictional facts subject to superior court rectification.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to other taxing statutes; SDO could decide gross income but found exceeded limit.

holdings.text: Notice under s.15(3) issued by Sub-Divisional Officer unauthorised when gross income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Only proper assessing authority (Collector here) can issue s.15(3) notice; SDO lost jurisdiction upon finding fact.

holdings.text: Board of Revision quashed the s.15(3) notice issued by Sub-Divisional Officer by setting aside assessment for want of jurisdiction and directing fresh assessment after notice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Effective quashing inferred from setting aside proceedings and requiring fresh notice.

holdings.text: Collector cannot commence fresh assessment relying on general notice under s.15(1) where special s.15(3) notice was invalid and proceedings set aside.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid special notice taints return; cannot revert to general notice post-expiry; fresh s.15(3) needed but time-barred.

holdings.text: Collector's notice under s.25 quashed by Board's order; fresh notice required for assessment under Board's direction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25 proceedings substituted invalid assessment, hence invalid; Board's direction mandates new notice, time-barred.

holdings.text: Court's jurisdiction limited to question referred under s.24; not deciding validity of Board's setting aside lower orders.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference. [...] The question whether the order passed by the Board setting aside the orders of assessment of the Sub-Divisional Officer and of the Collector and even of the Commissioner is justifiable in law is not referred to us. We are only concerned to deal with the limited question whether the Board had authority on the view expressed by it to make the order directing re-assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory jurisdiction confines to referred question; other issues not before court.

holdings.text: Respondent escapes tax liability due to authorities' errors, but fresh assessment cannot contravene statutory time limits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity cannot override clear statutory bars on notices and limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference. [...] The question whether the order passed by the Board setting aside the orders of assessment of the Sub-Divisional Officer and of the Collector and even of the Commissioner is justifiable in law is not referred to us. We are only concerned to deal with the limited question whether the Board had authority on the view expressed by it to make the order directing re-assessment.
The High Court was therefore right in the answer which it recorded.
